abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment identifies
            likely adverse environmental impacts connected with the
            Participatory Management of Protected Areas Project in six
            categories:: (i) load capacity; (ii) visual impact; (iii)
            natural environment deterioration; (iv) solid and liquid
            waste; (v) fire and emissions; and (vi) hosts and visitors
            security. Some of those impacts are discussed in this
            summary: Camping sites will be located strategically to
            avoid harming vegetation, forest animals and
            plants-especially endangered species-and water and soil.
            Adhering to camping ethics will be reinforced with visitors.
            Drainage systems will be built to protect the infrastructure
            of protected areas from flooding. Visitors will be educated
            on the prohibition of collecting plants and animals, proper
            waste disposal, restricted access areas, and regulations for
            using footpaths, etc. Solar, wind or water will be used as
            energy sources. Latrines and other installations will
            collect and store liquid and solid waste. Fire emergency
            plans will be issued. Existing infrastructure will be
            adapted to blend in visually with its surroundings or
            replaced and cables will be buried. Electric generators will
            be operated within closed structures to prevent spills and
            reduce noise. Road repair will be done with light equipment
            to avoid damage to vegetation and to soil. Where roads would
            possibly interfere with forest animals, adequate signage
            will be posted. The number of vehicles will be limited in
            sensitive environs.
